title: About the Smart Charging Project
text: This image was generated using DALLE 3.

title: About the Smart Charging Project
text:
Project Summary
This project aims to understand BEV owners’ preferences with respect to participating in the Smart Charging programs to improve grid resilience and enable greater integration of renewable energy onto the grid. The three-year project will be performed in two research thrusts:

Thrust One: Measure and model BEV charging preferences using conjoint survey.
Thrust Two: Simulate grid performance under different SMC and V2G scenarios.

The Smart Charging programs contain both SMC and V2G:

SMC is short for “Supplier-Managed Charging”. It allows the charging stations to monitor, manage, and even restrict the charging process to optimize energy consumption.
V2G is short for “Vehicle-to-Grid”. It allows bidirectional charging, so that the vehicle can discharge a certain amount of electricity back to the grid to further optimize energy consumption by balancing supply and demand.

The EV charging survey for the first thrust can be accessed here:

 EV Charging Survey 

The second thrust is also in early stages, and we are coordinating with partners to begin modeling grid performance under different BEV loading scenarios.
This project is supported by the the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation’s Energy and Environment Program.

title: FAQ
text:
BEV - BEV is short for “Battery Electrical Vehicles”. It is a type of electric vehicle (EV) that solely rely on electricity stored in batteries for propulsion. BEV does not have a gasoline engine. The key components of a BEV include an electric motor, a battery pack, and a control system.
Smart Charging - Smart Charging means to control and monitor the BEV charging process. In our project, it contains SMC and V2G.
SMC - SMC is short for “Supplier-Managed Charging”. It allows the charging stations to monitor, manage, and even restrict the charging process to optimize energy consumption. Specifically, SMC monitors and controls charging window and amount, to make sure they are mostly charged during the off-peak periods of the electricity demand.
V2G - V2G is short for “Vehicle-to-Grid”. It allows bidirectional charging, so that the vehicle can discharge a certain amount of electricity back to the grid to further optimize energy consumption by balancing supply and demand.
Conjoint Survey - A conjoint survey question packs different attributes together into each option, so that when participants make choices, they choose the whole package instead of only one attribute. For example, when I choose to buy an iPhone, I accept its expensive price, moderate signal, and durable quality at the same time. In this case, choosing to buy a phone is a conjoint question.

title: FAQ
text:
Q & A
Why Smart Charging - As BEVs are becoming a considerable part of vehicles, it is urgent to have a better power management process. The Smart Charging programs contribute to a zero-carbon power generation, and will be valuable to both the environment and the participants, including the grid providers and the BEV owners.
Why Conjoint Survey - A conjoint survey is a pilot simulation to people’s willingness of adopting to the smart charging program. By a proper modeling, executing, and analysis process, we’ll know in what conditions will BEV owners participate in the smart charging program, and how the program will be in details.

title: Home
text:
BEV (Battery Electric Vehicle) is an important solution to reduce \(CO_2\) and air pollution from vehicles. As BEVs gain popularity, managing their electric load on the grid will become increasingly important.
This project aims to understand BEV owners’ preferences of adopting the Smart Charging programs to improve grid resilience and enable greater integration of renewable energy onto the grid. The program contains both SMC (Supplier-Managed Charging) and V2G (Vehicle-to-Grid). See the About page for more details on the project.
This project is supported by the the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation’s Energy and Environment Program.

title: People
text:
This project is led by PI John Paul Helveston from The George Washington University in a partnership with researchers from UC Irvine, UC Davis, and RIT. The team consists of the following members:





John Paul Helveston, Ph.D. (ORCID: 0000-0002-2657-9191)
John Paul Helveston is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Engineering Management and Systems Engineering at the George Washington University. He studies technological change, with a particular interest in accelerating the transition to environmentally sustainable and energy-saving technologies.







Pingfan Hu (ORCID: 0009-0001-4877-4844)
Pingfan Hu is a Ph.D. student in Systems Engineering at the George Washington University, supervised by PI John Helveston. His primary research topic is the adoption of BEV Smart Charging by conjoint surveys.







Brian Tarroja, Ph.D., P.E. (ORCID: 0000-0002-7736-8642)
Brian Tarroja is a researcher and educator focused on improving the robustness of strategies to carry out the transition to a cleaner, decarbonized energy system. His research centers on understanding how to co-optimize concurrent transitions in energy, water, and transportation infrastructures to maximize beneficial outcomes and avoid or minimize harmful consequences.







Matthew Dean, Ph.D. (ORCID: 0000-0002-0346-4316)
Matthew Dean is an Assistant Professor at UC Irvine conducting research at the intersection of transportation engineering and energy systems. His work prepares cities for emergent shared mobility services, strengthens our decarbonization goals by managing distributed energy assets, and creates healthy communities by getting people out biking, walking, and rolling.







Kate Forrest, Ph.D. (ORCID: 0000-0001-6375-1299)
Kate E. Forrest is currently a Senior Scientist at Advanced Power and Energy Program (APEP) at the University of California, Irvine. She is an environmental scientist and engineer passionate about clean energy, environmental advocacy, sustainable energy and transportation solutions, science policy, and educational outreach.







Eric Hittinger, Ph.D. (ORCID: 0000-0001-8439-4016)
Eric Hittinger is an Associate Professor of Public Policy at Rochester Institute of Technology, WILL International Chair at University of Lille, and President-Elect of the US Association for Energy Economics. His research is focused on energy policy, particularly the opportunities and challenges associated with new technologies such as energy storage, renewables, EVs, and efficiency.







Alan Jenn, Ph.D. (ORCID: 0000-0003-4232-0697)
Alan Jenn is an Assistant Professor at the EV group of the Institute of Transportation Studies at the University of California, Davis as well as an affiliate at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. His research is focused on PEVs: integration with the electric grid, adoption of the technology, use in ride-hailing companies, and its impact on transportation finance.

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Recall: Homogeneous Utility Model
All our past analyses are Homogeneous Utility Models, meaning we consider all participants as homogeneous, so that everyone has the same utility coefficients of \(\boldsymbol{\beta}\).
\[
\tilde {u_j} = \boldsymbol{\beta}'\mathbf{x}_j + \tilde {\epsilon_j} = \beta_1 x_{j1} + \beta_2 x_{j2} + \ldots + \tilde {\epsilon_j}
\]
The \(\boldsymbol{\beta}\) values consist of \(\hat {\beta}\) and \(\sigma\), which are estimated values and Std Err:





Est
β^1
β^2
...
β^m


Std.Err.
σ1
σ2
...
σm







However, in real world, it’s impossible to have homogeneous participants. We use different methods to create heterogeneous models. The 2 of them are:

Interaction Model, where we divide participants into groups, each with their own \(\beta\) coefficients.
Mixed Logit Model, where we span each \(\beta\) coefficient as normal distribution (or other dist.) instead of point estimate.

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Heterogeneous Models
Heterogeneous models allow for different participants to have different coefficients. There are 2 models that we want to discuss:


1. Interaction Model
aka Observed Heterogeneity












Group 1


Group 2



Estimate
Std. Err.
Estimate
Std. Err.




β^1
σ1
β^1
σ1


β^2
σ2
β^2
σ2


...
...
...
...


β^m
σm
β^m
σm







Participants are divided into 2 groups, each with their own \(\beta\) coefficients.



2. Mixed Logit Model
aka Unobserved Heterogeneity





Estimate




β^1 ∼ N( μ^1 , σ^1 )


β^2 ∼ N( μ^2 , σ^2 )


...


β^m ∼ N( μ^m , σ^m )







Each \(\beta\) coefficient is spanned as normal distribution instead of point estimate.

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Model 1: Interaction Model


We start from a simple homogeneous model:
\[
\tilde {u_j} = \beta_1 x_{j1} + \tilde {\epsilon_j}
\]
We assign 2 groups A and B, where \(\delta^B\) is an indicator:
\[
\begin{align}
\tilde {u_j} &= \beta_1 x_{j1} + \beta_2 x_{j1} \delta^B + \tilde {\epsilon_j} \\
&= (\beta_1 + \beta_2 \delta^B) x_{j1} + \tilde {\epsilon_j}
\end{align}
\]
The reason why we can directly add the \(\beta\)s of A and B with a uniformed \(\tilde {\epsilon_j}\) is that the error term follows the same Gumbel distribution.



The effect of \(x_{j1}\) is different for Groups A and B:

For Group A, it’s only \(\hat{\beta}_1\);
For Group B, it’s \(\hat{\beta}_1 + \hat{\beta}_2\).

In the interaction model, the \(\hat{\beta}_1\) and \(\hat{\beta}_2\) values are:





Par.
Interpretation




β^1
Effect of xj1 for group A


β^2
Difference in effect of xj1 between groups A and B

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Practice Question 1
Suppose we use the following utility model to describe preferences for cars:
\[
\tilde {u_j} = \beta_1 x_j^{price} + \beta_2 x_j^{mpg} + \beta_3 \delta_j^{elec} + \tilde {\epsilon_j}
\]

Using interactions, write out a model that accounts for differences in the effects of \(x_j^{price}\), \(x_j^{mpg}\), and \(\delta_j^{elec}\) between two groups: A and B.
\[
\tilde {u_j} = \beta_1 x_j^{price} + \beta_2 x_j^{mpg} + \beta_3 \delta_j^{elec} + \beta_4 x_j^{price} \delta^B + \beta_5 x_j^{mpg} \delta^B + \beta_6 \delta_j^{elec} \delta^B + \tilde {\epsilon_j}
\]
Write out the effects of \(x_j^{price}\), \(x_j^{mpg}\), and \(\delta_j^{elec}\) for each group.






Group
A
B




xjprice
β1
β1 + β4


xjmpg
β2
β2 + β5


δjelec
β3
β3 + β6

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Hypothesis Test
We use the simulation method to perform the hypothesis test, and see if there is significant difference between Group A and Group B.


Use R code to perform the simulation:
# Construct beta and hessian
beta = c(b1 = -0.7, b2 = 0.1)
hessian = matrix(c(-6000,  50,
                    50,   -6000),
                 ncol = 2, byrow = TRUE)
covariance = -1*(solve(hessian))

# Simulate draws for 10^5 times
draws = as.data.frame(MASS::mvrnorm(10^5, beta, covariance))

# Work out the utility model coefficients beta
b1_A = draws$b1
b1_B = draws$b1 + draws$b2

# Calculate confidence Intervals
mean(b1_A)
mean(b1_B)
quantile(b1_A, c(0.025, 0.975))
quantile(b1_B, c(0.025, 0.975))



The mean and quantile values are:
> mean(b1_A)
[1] -0.7000618
> mean(b1_B)
[1] -0.6000408
> quantile(b1_A, c(0.025, 0.975))
      2.5%      97.5%
-0.7253724 -0.6748339
> quantile(b1_B, c(0.025, 0.975))
      2.5%      97.5%
-0.6358317 -0.5642215
Since these 2 confidence intervals do not overlap, there is significant evidence that Group A is different from Group B.

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Practice Question 2
Suppose we estimate the following utility model describing preferences for chocolate bars between two groups: A & B
\[
\tilde {u_j} = \beta_1 x_j^{price} + \beta_2 x_j^{cacao} + \beta_3 x_j^{price} \delta^B + \beta_4 x_j^{cacao} \delta^B + \tilde {\epsilon_j}
\]



Use the mvrnorm() function from the MASS library to generate 10,000 draws of the model coefficients.
Use the draws to compute the mean and 95% confidence intervals of the effects of \(x_j^{price}\) and \(x_j^{cacao}\) for each group (A&B).

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Question 2 Solution


Codes
# Construct beta and hessian
beta = c(b1 = -0.7, b2 = 0.1, b3 = 0.2, b4 = 0.8)
hessian = matrix(c(-6000, 50,  60,  70,
                    50,  -700, 50,  100,
                    60,   50, -300, 20,
                    70,   100, 20, -6000),
                 ncol = 4, byrow = TRUE)
covariance = -1*(solve(hessian))

# Simulate draws for 10^5 times
draws = as.data.frame(MASS::mvrnorm(10^5, beta, covariance))

# Work out the utility model coefficients beta
b1_A = draws$b1
b2_A = draws$b2
b1_B = draws$b1 + draws$b3
b2_B = draws$b2 + draws$b4

# Calculate confidence Intervals
mean(b1_A)
mean(b2_A)
mean(b1_B)
mean(b2_B)
quantile(b1_A, c(0.025, 0.975))
quantile(b2_A, c(0.025, 0.975))
quantile(b1_B, c(0.025, 0.975))
quantile(b2_B, c(0.025, 0.975))

Results
> mean(b1_A)
[1] -0.7000142
> mean(b2_A)
[1] 0.1000435
> mean(b1_B)
[1] -0.4998727
> mean(b2_B)
[1] 0.9000659
> quantile(b1_A, c(0.025, 0.975))
      2.5%      97.5% 
-0.7254443 -0.6747621 
> quantile(b2_A, c(0.025, 0.975))
      2.5%      97.5% 
0.02545381 0.17482052 
> quantile(b1_B, c(0.025, 0.975))
      2.5%      97.5% 
-0.6186359 -0.3814665 
> quantile(b2_B, c(0.025, 0.975))
     2.5%     97.5% 
0.8200561 0.9804029 
Both \(\beta\) values of A and B are significantly different.

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Model 2: Mixed Logit Model (MXL)
In the MXL model, we assume each \(\beta\) is distributed across the population, so that we convert from a point estimate \(\hat {\beta}\) to a range containing an estimated mean \(\hat {\mu}\) and Std Err \(\hat {\sigma}\).


Standard vs Mixed Logit
A standard logit uses point estimate, whose PDF is a solid value:
\[
P_j = \frac{e^{v_j}}{\sum_{k=1}^{J} e^{v_k}}
\]
A mixed logit uses integration, whose PDF is an area under the curve:
\[
P_j = \int \left( \frac{e^{v_j}}{\sum_{k=1}^{J} e^{v_k}} \right) f(\beta) d\beta
\]



Use Simulation for MXL

Draw a \(\beta\) value from \(f(\beta)\), label it \(\beta^r\).
Calculate the standard logit function using \(\beta^r\):
\[
P_j^r = \frac{e^{v_j^r}}{\sum_{k=1}^{J} e^{v_k^r}}
\]
Simulate R times of draws, sum and divide by R:
\[
\hat{P}_j = \frac{1}{R} \sum_{r=1}^{R} P_j^r
\]

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
MXL Simulation using R Code
We use the logitr package to simulate the MXL model. Take this chocolate example:
\[
\tilde{u}_j = \beta_1 x_j^{\text{price}} + \beta_2 x_j^{\text{cacao}} + \varepsilon_j \\
\beta_1 \sim N(\mu_1, \sigma_1), \quad \beta_2 \sim N(\mu_2, \sigma_2)
\]


R Code

library(logitr)

model = logitr(
    data     = data,
    outcome  = 'choice',
    obsID    = 'obsID',
    pars     = c('price', 'cacao'),
    randPars = c(price = 'n', cacao = 'n')
)




Interpretation

Use the logitr() function to generate standard and mixed logit models.
By setting randPars, we define the individually distributed variables price and cacao, which results in a mixed logit model.
By setting randPars values as 'n', we define them as “Normally Distributed”. The value 'ln' means log normal distribution.

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Practice Question 3

Load the logitr package, which loads the yogurt data frame.
Use the logitr package to estimate the following homogeneous model: \[
\tilde{u}_j = \beta_1 x_j^{\text{price}} + \beta_2 \delta_j^{\text{feat}} + \beta_3 \delta_j^{\text{dannon}} + \beta_4 \delta_j^{\text{highland}} + \beta_5 \delta_j^{\text{weight}} + \varepsilon_j
\] where the three \(\sigma\) coefficients are dummies for Dannon, Highland, and Weight Watchers brands and Yoplait is the baseline brand.
Use the logitr package to estimate the same model but with the following mixing distributions: \[
\beta_1 \sim N(\mu_1, \sigma_1) \\
\beta_2 \sim N(\mu_2, \sigma_2)
\]

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Question 3 Solution


Standard Logit Model
Code:
# Load package
library(logitr)

# Standard model
model_standard = logitr(
    data     = yogurt,
    outcome  = 'choice',
    obsID    = 'obsID',
    pars     = c('price', 'feat', 'brand')
)

# Model coefficients
coef(model_standard)
Result:
> coef(model_standard)
       price         feat  brandhiland  brandweight 
  -0.3665546    0.4914392   -3.7154773   -0.6411384 
brandyoplait 
   0.7345195 



Mixed Logit Model
Code:
# Load package
library(logitr)

# Standard model
model_mixed = logitr(
    data     = yogurt,
    outcome  = 'choice',
    obsID    = 'obsID',
    pars     = c('price', 'feat', 'brand'),
    randPars = c(price = 'n', feat = 'n')
)

# Model coefficients
coef(model_mixed)
Result:
> coef(model_mixed)
        price          feat   brandhiland   brandweight 
-0.3930417945  0.2637660327 -3.9897865512 -0.6637300503 
 brandyoplait      sd_price       sd_feat 
 0.7949907357 -0.0009494817 -2.4318056761

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Enroll in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Reflect


What I have learned

Constructed my own theme.scss for a good-looking revealjs slides.
Learned 2 heterogeneous models: interaction model and mixed logit model.
Practiced on using R code to solve for both models. For interaction model, we simulate the draws with mvrnorm(); for mixed logit model, we use logitr() to construct and analyze the models.




My questions

I’m getting used to make revealjs slides, but I wonder how it can be compatible with my notes website. I also want to upload it online and have it accessed in my notes.
I’m having trouble with applying personalized fonts. For example, I tried “Ubuntu” and “Noto” fonts but they didn’t work. I didn’t have this problem in webpages. I suspect revealjs can only access online-sourced fonts.







Pingfan Hu

title: Slides
text: Press “F” for full screen, or access the full screen version here:  Project Slides .

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Introduction

BEVs (Battery Electric Vehicles) can reduce \(CO_2\) and prevent air pollution.
But managing BEV charging can become a problem for the grid.
Smart charging can help, but depends on user acceptance.







As an introduction…

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Research Questions

Sensitivity: How do changes in smart charging program features influence BEV owners’ willingness to opt in?
Market Share: Under what conditions will BEV owners be more willing to opt in to smart charging programs?


Conjoint survey to collect BEV owners’ willingness.


Mixed logit model to evaluate utilities for simulations.



Here we have 2 research questions…
For sensitivity, we want to measure and quantify the program features’ influence to owners’ willingness.
For market share, we wonder under what conditions they will opt in.

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Method: Survey Design

Discrete choice experiment (conjoint analysis)
Two types of programs: SMC and V2G
5 attributes for each program type
6 choice questions for SMC, 6 for V2G
Each question: 2 program options + “not interested” option



SMC Attributes:

Enrollment Cash
Monthly Cash
Override Allowance
Minimum Threshold
Guaranteed Threshold


V2G Attributes:

Enrollment Cash
Occurrence Cash
Monthly Occurrence
Lower Bound
Guaranteed Threshold

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Data Collection

Online survey via Facebook and Instagram ads
Target: Current BEV owners
Screening process to ensure BEV ownership
Current sample: 858 total responses

815 completed SMC questions
414 completed V2G questions

Ongoing data collection, target: ~1,500 responses

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Model Specification

Random utility model
Probability of choosing alternative j:

\[ P_j = \frac{e^{v_j}}{\sum_{k=1}^{J} e^{v_k}} \]

Mixed logit (MXL) model to account for preference heterogeneity
Estimated using logitr R package
100 multi-starts, 500 Sobol draws for simulation

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Results: SMC Model

Utility of “No Choice”: 5.52
Most influential attributes:

Monthly Cash
Guaranteed Threshold

Least influential: Minimum Threshold

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Results: V2G Model

Utility of “No Choice”: 5.42
Most influential attributes:

Occurrence Cash
Enrollment Cash

Higher baseline participation rate compared to SMC

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Sensitivity Analysis






Steeper slop indicates higher sensitivity.


So, how to judge which one is more sensitive and which one is not? We sketched these sensitivity plots…

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Market Simulations


SMC Simulation:

78% enrollment with $20 Monthly Cash
88% enrollment with additional $300 Enrollment Cash
Flexibility can substitute for some monetary incentives











V2G Simulation:

93% enrollment with full monetary incentives
V2G success highly dependent on utility budget

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Discussion

Recurring payments (Monthly Cash) more important than one-time incentives
Range anxiety reflected in importance of Guaranteed Threshold for SMC
V2G participants show higher willingness to participate, but sample size smaller
Trade-off between monetary incentives and flexibility in program design

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Conclusion

Incentives are vital for smart charging programs to success.
BEV owners show willingness to participate in smart charging programs
Key factors: monetary incentives and guaranteed driving ranges
V2G programs may attract more willing participants
Future work:

Collect more data for subgroup analysis
Integrate consumer preferences into grid simulations
Estimate benefit-cost trade-offs for utilities






Pingfan Hu - IEEE VPPC 2024

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs

Questions?

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Background
BEVs (Battery Electric Vehicles) are clean, but the source of electricity might not be clean.

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Intro

Battery Electric Vehicles (BEVs) are crucial for decarbonization
Unmanaged BEV charging can strain the grid
Smart charging programs can help manage demand
Two types: Supplier-Managed Charging (SMC) and Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G)
Challenge: Ensuring BEV owner participation

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Introducing Smart Charging


Supplier Managed Charging (SMC)

V2G Attributes:

Enrollment Cash
Occurrence Cash
Monthly Occurrence
Lower Bound
Guaranteed Threshold




Unmanaged BEV charging can strain the grid
Smart charging programs can help manage demand
Two types: Supplier-Managed Charging (SMC) and Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G)
Challenge: Ensuring BEV owner participation

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
SMC - Supplier Managed Charging

SMC smooths out overnight EV charging demand.
Electricity demand is controlled below capacity threshold.







This is the first type of smart charging…

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
V2G - Vehicle-to-Grid






Then, the other way of smart charging, is called V2G…

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Program Design


Conjoint Questions:

Monetary Incentives: one-time payment upon enrollment and recurring payment per month (SMC) or per event (V2G).
Charging Limitations: battery lower bound and guaranteed threshold.
Flexibility: override allowance (SMC) and monthly occurrence (V2G).

Demographic Questions:

Heterogeneity: How different the BEV owners are based on their demographic information.




Conjoint Questions + Demographic Questions

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Program Design




V2G Attributes:

Enrollment Cash
Occurrence Cash
Monthly Occurrence
Lower Bound
Guaranteed Threshold




Unmanaged BEV charging can strain the grid
Smart charging programs can help manage demand
Two types: Supplier-Managed Charging (SMC) and Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G)
Challenge: Ensuring BEV owner participation

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Program Design {.smaller=false}

Monetary Incentives: including one-time payment upon enrollment, and recurring payment per month (SMC) or per event (V2G).
Charging Limitations: battery lower bound and guaranteed threshold.
Flexibility: override allowance (SMC) and monthly occurrence (V2G).

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Sensitivity Analysis










Monetary incentives show higher sensitivity in both programs
Importance of guaranteed threshold for SMC

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Tornado Plots

















Monetary incentives are important.
Recurring incentive is more important than one-time.
For SMC, range anxiety is vital, since it happens regularly.
For V2G, usability is compromised.
Diminishing returns exist.

But for V2G, money is more important than flexibility…

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Survey Structure


Conjoint Questions:

Monetary Incentives: one-time + recurring payment.
Charging Limitations: remaining battery.
Flexibility: monthly override (SMC) or occurrence (V2G).

Demographic Questions:

Heterogeneity: How different the BEV owners are based on their demographic information.
Aspects: BEV ownership, charging habits, commute method, age, income, house type, family size, etc.

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
section: Mixed Logit Models Using logitr R Package
text:
Mixed Logit Models Using logitr R Package
\[
\begin{align*}
u_j = v_j + \epsilon_j = \beta' x + \epsilon_j
\qquad
P_j = \frac{e^{v_j}}{\sum_{k=1}^{J} e^{v_k}}
\end{align*}
\]


SMC Estimates






V2G Estimates








Estimates show a resistance to accepting SMC or V2G.

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Future Work
Data Collection

Other than social media, use survey panels to collect more responses.
Increase data size from 800 to 2000.

Modeling

Subgroup analysis considering heterogeneity.
More modeling techniques such as Apollo Choice Modeling.

Simulation

Apply customer preferences to grid simulation.
Estimate benefit-cost trade-offs for utilities.





Pingfan Hu - IEEE VPPC 2024

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Introduction

BEVs (Battery Electric Vehicles) can reduce \(CO_2\) and prevent air pollution.
But managing BEV charging can become a problem for the grid.
Smart charging can help, but depends on user acceptance.







As an introduction…

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
SMC - Supplier Managed Charging

SMC smooths out overnight EV charging demand.
Electricity demand is controlled below capacity threshold.







This is the first type of smart charging…

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
V2G - Vehicle-to-Grid






Then, the other way of smart charging, is called V2G…

title: Measuring Consumer Willingness to Participate in BEV Smart Charging Programs
text:
Research Questions

Sensitivity: How do changes in smart charging program features influence BEV owners’ willingness to opt in?
Market Share: Under what conditions will BEV owners be more willing to opt in to smart charging programs?


Conjoint survey to collect BEV owners’ willingness.


Mixed logit model to evaluate utilities for simulations.



Here we have 2 research questions…
For sensitivity, we want to measure and quantify the program features’ influence to owners’ willingness.
For market share, we wonder under what conditions they will opt in.
